data.title: Update TS extension to target es6
data.body: Updates the TypeScript extension to target ES6. The main change here was renaming `Map` to `ObjectMap` so that our type does not collide with the builtin es6 `Map` type definition.

data.title: Add screenshots to Linux packages

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
We're getting an .appdata.xml file soon (https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/pull/16169) to go along with the packages which allow defining of screenshots for the packages.

We need URLs for up to 5 screenshots (16:9 ratio), each with a caption that will be localized. One of them needs to be defined as the "default" screenshot. I'll find out the ideal resolution for these soon.

data.title: Finalize package wording on Linux packages and localize

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
This is the current wording is not localized, we should do so for both deb and rpm packages.

Summary:

> Code editing. Redefined.

Description:

> Visual Studio Code is a new choice of tool that combines the simplicity of a code editor with what developers need for the core edit-build-debug cycle. See https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/setup/linux for installation instructions and FAQ.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2193314/21154397/1c9f2868-c123-11e6-9de7-c5f4261686df.png)

Some things to consider:

- We currently refer to the application as just `Visual Studio Code` regardless of the build type (stable, insiders, OSS), we can change this to be more specific (`Visual Studio Code - Insiders`, `Code - OSS`, ...).
- The link cannot be clicked and must be copied and pasted into a browser. I'm not sure this is adding much value.

Hello there!

It's been a damn good year!

Last month vscode project had over **1500** active community members, which is an absolute Github record! Especially remarkable considering the fact that you have done it in such short period of time!

Microsoft have the biggest open-source community, what a time we live in :)

You can see your stats here:
https://ossmetrics.com/leaderboard
https://ossmetrics.com/Microsoft/vscode

Wish you a happy new year and continue to be awesome!

data.title: Can not switch from markdown preview back to regular editor
data.body:
1. Open a markdown file, e.g our docs
2. Open a preview of that file side by side
3. Continue working, after some time only have the preview opened
4. Click on the action to go back to the regular editor

Sorry for not exact steps - can not repro it easily. But it happens 100% after some time working with markdown and previewin.
FYI @joaomoreno since I think you touched some inmemory models

Notice error, also notice that the title of that preview becomes 'preview of 42' so it seems like the preview has lost it's original model

![screen shot 2016-12-13 at 16 59 37](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1926584/21147603/dd874f56-c155-11e6-8b5c-423ec698f339.png)

data.title: Not all keystrokes recorded when using git bash for Windows as the integrated shell
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.7.2 (7ba55c5860b152d999dda59393ca3ebeb1b5c85f, 2016-11-21T22:06:37.428Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.10586
- Extensions:

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|EditorConfig|EditorConfig|0.3.4|
|tslint|eg2|0.5.33|
|vscode-JS-CSS-HTML-formatter|lonefy|0.2.1|
|prettify-json|mohsen1|0.0.3|
|vscode-icons|robertohuertasm|1.5.2|
|vim|vscodevim|0.4.2|

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Install git for windows (https://git-for-windows.github.io/)
2. Setup the git bash shell as the integrated terminal for vscode (workspace settings: "terminal.integrated.shell.windows": "C:\\progra~1\\Git\\bin\\bash.exe")
3. Type text into the integrated shell window (quickly, typed). 
4. When you press return to send the command, some of the text isn't sent to the command window. I'm not sure if this behavious occurs more frequently when backspace is used.

data.title: Allow to open problems view without taking keyboard focus

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
I'm trying to have an extension automatically (with config) open up the Problems panel after it does a syntax check compile.  I can do:
```
vscode.commands.executeCommand("workbench.action.showErrorsWarnings");
```
but this opens the panel *and focuses it*.  This last part is the problem.  Hunting through the code, this is a `ToggleErrorsAndWarningsAction`, which extends `TogglePanelAction`, which ultimately runs:
```
return this.panelService.openPanel(this.panelId, true);
```
That `true` argument is the problem here -- I want to call `panelService.openPanel` with `false` for the focus argument.  I'm not clear on what the extensibility API boundary is, and how I can get to things like the panel service -- is it possible to do that from an extension?

data.title: Accessibility: MAS40B: Inspect: 'Name' property is empty for  "Search results" pane on Extensions sidebar area.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6.1
- OS Version:1607

**Steps to Reproduce:**
      1.Open Visual studio code editor.
      2.Using "Ctrl+Shift+X",key navigate to 'Extensions' window.
      3. Tab to "Search results" pane present below 'Search Extensions in Marketplace' search edit box.
      4. Using Inspect, observe its "Name" property. 
**Expected Result:**
      "Name" property should not be empty. Pane should have a meaningful and appropriate name.
**Actual Result:**
      'Name' property is empty for the Search Results pane.
      Narrator Info:- Narrator announces as "Tab selected, requires selection contains 9 items, Starting".
      NVDA Info:- NVDA focus goes to the pane but announces nothing.
**User Impact**
Users relying on screen readers will get confused if the name property is not meaningful and inappropriate.

![search results pane name empty](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/22956130/21139063/21ead11c-c157-11e6-9e1f-80f237c63f81.png)

data.body:

3. This is due to the fact that node2 does not return `supportsRestartFrame: true`

data.title: Support auto detect of file encoding
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.2
- OS Version: 6.1.7601

data.title: Waterfall startup sequence
data.body:
The overall startup sequence from starting the main process to starting the renderer process is waterfall'ish, esp. since we don't just wait for the app to be ready but because we do many things before starting the renderer (which itself doesn't do anything else than loading code for the first 1 second). Let's identify what can run after or in parallel to getting the renderer ready. Also, I have created a benchmark, stripped down, electron app, which should set the baseline - we can't get faster but should strive to become as close as possible. 

The timings for a simple app (attached) are 

```
app,started: (absolute) 0ms, (relative) 0
app,ready: (absolute) 58ms, (relative) 58
mainWindow,created: (absolute) 90ms, (relative) 32
renderer,html: (absolute) 378ms, (relative) 288
```

VS Code (on my mac) takes ~750ms before loading the main window (compare to `mainWindow,created`) and ~1200ms before loading the big chunk of code (workbench.min.js, compare with `renderer,html`). That makes roughly 600ms that are spending somewhere. Since that is roughly the time it takes to load the main portion of our code, I wonder if those 600ms initialisation work can run in parallel, while we load the code of the workbench.

data.title: Default new window position and size
data.body:
When I open a new window in VS Code (Ctrl/Cmd+Shift+N), the new window takes about 1/3 of the screen and I need to manually resize it to make it bigger.  (On Windows this may not be a huge issue since there's the maximize button. But on a Mac, laborious manual resizing is needed to keep windows in the same space.)

Wanted behavior: The window is sized and positioned with the size and position taken from the last user-sized and the last user-positioned window.

Possible workaround if this is hard to implement: add an option to specify new default window size and an option to specify a new default window position, both in pixels.

This is **NOT** a duplicate of #9534 **nor** a duplicate of #422.
